content.description: Very slabby. Friends were able to send it with no hands. Great beginner route, but not so hot in the rain!
content.protection: Some bolts, bring gear to build an anchor on the trees
content.location: 30 ft right of the crack at Harriet Hunt

content.description: Slabby route right of the arete. Begin with a slight scrambly start, then follow the thin crack all the way up. Anchor must be built around trees at the top. Either top out or take the trail off the road just past the crag.
content.protection: No bolts, thin crack for nuts and small cams. Must build anchor on ledge above, around trees.
content.location: Right of the arete and center route.

content.description: climb up the slab to the center of the vertical wall. head directly up the middle to the horizontal cracks and traverse left to the final ledge (crux moves). from there, its one simple move to the finish
content.protection: top rope   (see route "the aret" for more info on protection)
content.location: same start as "the aret" but stick to the center of the vertical wall as opposed to the left side aret

content.description:
climb up the slab to the vertical section. stick to the left side of the wall on the aret. the crux is before the last ledge beneath the top. use a series of sidepulls with smeared feet so you dont barn-door off the face. reach for the final ledge and mantle. the top is one easy move away from there 

  note: if you use a top rope, you will have pro set up for the aret as well as the center route
content.protection: there are some ancient bolts up the aret, but they are drawn out pretty far. one piece of pro is a rusted out piton jammed in a horizintal crack way above the last bolt   if you set up a top-rope, check your anchor. the anchor bolts are very old. its best to build your own anchor using the trees at the top. i clip the bolts as a guide so the rope wont swing as much
content.location: the farthest left crag. over the slab and up the vertical wall

content.description: To my knowledge only one established crag exists in the Ketchikan vicinity but rumor has it there are a few more. One route has some ancient bolts but has brand new shiny anchors and the route next to it (slabby) has new bolts all the way up.
